author: Gregory Karp
title: United, swirling in CEO uncertainty, posts higher profits - Chicago Tribune
text:
Chicago-based United Continental Holdings, parent of United Airlines, on Thursday reported higher profits in the third quarter than the same period last year, but its earnings fell short of Wall Street expectations as the carrier tries to implement new customer-pleasing changes without the CEO that promised them.
The airline company has endured massive upheaval in its top ranks since its July quarterly earnings report, with three CEOs guiding the company over the past seven weeks.
In early September, CEO Jeff Smisek abruptly resigned along with two top lieutenants, due to ongoing internal and federal criminal probes associated with a New York-area port authority scandal. Smisek was replaced immediately by longtime board member Oscar Munoz, a top executive at rail company CSX.
Then a week ago, Munoz, 56, in just his sixth week on the job, suffered a heart attack and was hospitalized.
On Monday, Brett J. Hart, 46, a United vice president and general counsel, was named acting CEO, with Munoz on medical leave. United has given no timetable for the return of Munoz.
Hart, participating in a conference call with analysts and media Thursday, said his vision and plans for United align with those of Munoz, who spent much of his short tenure so far talking about improving flight reliability and service quality for passengers, as well as listening to customers and employees.
"We are using what he provided in terms of a vision as a lens for executing on our plan for the rest of this fiscal year," Hart said. "Those perspectives are entirely aligned, and there will be no dramatic changes."

(Chicago Tribune staff) Two concrete changes coming for customers, ones also highlighted by Munoz in an exclusive interview with the Tribune this month, involve coffee and the flight boarding procedure.
United has narrowed down the choices for a new premium coffee it serves onboard to three, said Jim Compton, chief revenue officer. He did not name the brands.
"That was something we heard loud and clear (from customers)," he said. "It's a small example of a cadence you're going to see across the company, relatively quickly." He said some of those changes will be introduced in the next several weeks and others before the end of the year.
And United this week started testing new boarding procedures at O'Hare International Airport, although officials did not elaborate on what those changes were.
"That's one of the things, quite frankly, that we hear a lot about," Compton said. Munoz previously said he didn't like how complicated United's boarding is.
Also, top customers have started getting a free drink in economy class when they don't get the upgraded seating they requested, Compton said.

(Phil Rosenthal) United, the largest carrier in Chicago and No. 2 in the world, reported a third-quarter profit of $1.7 billion, compared with $1.08 billion in the same quarter last year. Earnings of $4.53 per share fell short of the analyst consensus estimate of $4.55, according to FactSet.
Including a tax-related gain of $3.2 billion, United earned $4.82 billion, or $12.82 a share.
Quarterly revenue of $10.3 billion, a 2.4 percent decrease year-over-year, was in line with estimates.
U.S. airlines, including United, are enjoying a period of financial prosperity, benefiting from full planes and low fuel prices. However, United has continued to deal with operational and customer service woes, problems that Munoz during his short tenure pledged to fix.
United, Chicago's largest private-sector employer, linked the ouster of Smisek to investigations involving allegedly improperly currying favor with former Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Chairman David Samson. United reinstated a money-losing route from Newark to an airport near Samson's South Carolina vacation home. Also stepping down in connection with that investigation were the airline's executive vice president of communications and government affairs, Nene Foxhall, and its senior vice president of corporate and government affairs, Mark Anderson.
Shares of United were trading midday Thursday at $55.75, up 2.2 percent on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock is down 18.5 percent this year.
